background-color: White; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;Accounts payable and&#13;    accrued liabilities&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;(149,647&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;(4,177&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;(153,824&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;</elmd:RevenueInitialApplicationPeriodCumulativeEffectTransitionTabletextBlock>
    <us-gaap:RevenueFromContractWithCustomerTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Note&amp;#160;2. Revenues&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Revenue is measured based on consideration specified in the&#13;contract with a customer, adjusted for any applicable estimates of variable consideration and other factors affecting the transaction&#13;price, including noncash consideration, consideration paid or payable to customers and significant financing components. Revenue&#13;from all customers is recognized when a performance obligation is satisfied by transferring control of a distinct good or service&#13;to a customer, as further described below under &lt;i&gt;Performance obligations&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Individual promised goods and services in a contract are considered&#13;a performance obligation and accounted for separately if the individual good or service is distinct (i.e., the customer can benefit&#13;from the good or service on its own or with other resources that are readily available to the customer and the good or service&#13;is separately identifiable from other promises in the arrangement). If an arrangement includes multiple performance obligations,&#13;the consideration is allocated between the performance obligations in proportion to their estimated standalone selling price, unless&#13;discounts or variable consideration is attributable to one or more but not all the performance obligations. Costs related to products&#13;delivered are recognized in the period incurred, unless criteria for capitalization of costs under ASC 340-40, &amp;#8220;Other Assets&#13;and Deferred Costs&amp;#8221;, or other applicable guidance are met.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The Company includes shipping and handling fees in net revenues.&#13;Shipping and handling costs associated with the shipment of SmartVest Systems after control has transferred to a customer are accounted&#13;for as a fulfillment cost and are included in cost of revenues.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The timing of revenue recognition, billings and cash collections&#13;results in accounts receivable on the condensed balance sheets as further described below under &lt;i&gt;Accounts receivable &lt;/i&gt;and&#13;&lt;i&gt;Contract assets&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Disaggregation of revenues. &lt;/b&gt;In the following table, revenue&#13;is disaggregated by market:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" align="center" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 95%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="text-align: center;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; border-bottom: Black 1px solid"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;2018&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; padding-bottom: 1px"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; padding-bottom: 1px"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; border-bottom: Black 1px solid"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;2017 &lt;br /&gt;&#13;    As Adjusted&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; padding-bottom: 1px"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: rgb(214,243,232); font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 39%; text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Commercial&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 1%; text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 1%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%; text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 12%; text-align: right; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;3,477,768&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 1%; text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 1%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%; text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; border-bottom: Black 1px solid; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; border-bottom: Black 1px solid; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;351,127&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 1px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; border-bottom: Black 1px solid; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; border-bottom: Black 1px solid; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;372,312&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 1px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: rgb(214,243,232); font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Total&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;7,330,927&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;6,490,451&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;14,053,321&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;12,398,959&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 3px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Revenues in the Company&amp;#8217;s home care and international&#13;markets are recognized at a point in time when control passes to the customer upon product shipment or delivery. Revenues in the&#13;Company&amp;#8217;s institutional market include sales recognized at a point in time upon shipment or delivery as well as revenues&#13;recognized over time under operating leases.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Performance obligations and Transaction Price. &lt;/b&gt; A performance&#13;obligation is a promise in a contract to transfer a distinct good or service to the customer and is the unit of account under ASC&#13;606. A contract&amp;#8217;s transaction price is allocated to each distinct performance obligation in proportion to the standalone&#13;selling price for each and recognized as revenue when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. The Company&amp;#8217;s performance&#13;obligations and the timing or method of revenue recognition in each of the Company&amp;#8217;s markets are discussed below:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Home care market&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;/b&gt; In the Company&amp;#8217;s&#13;home care market, its customers are patients who use the SmartVest&amp;#174; System. The various models of the SmartVest&amp;#174; System&#13;are comprised of three main components - a generator, a vest and a connecting hose that are sold together as an integrated unit.&#13;Accordingly, in contracts within the home care market, the Company regards the SmartVest&amp;#174; System to be a single performance&#13;obligation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;The Company makes available to its home care patients&#13;limited post-sale services that are not material in the context of the contracts, either individually or taken together, and therefore&#13;does not consider them to be performance obligations. The costs associated with the services are accrued and expensed when the&#13;related revenues are recognized. As such, transactions in the home care market consist of a single performance obligation, the&#13;SmartVest System.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;Home care patients generally will rely on third-party&#13;payers, including commercial payers and governmental payers such as Medicare, Medicaid, and the Veteran&amp;#8217;s Administration&#13;to cover and reimburse all or part of the cost of the SmartVest System. The third-party payers&amp;#8217; reimbursement programs fall&#13;into three types, distinguished by the differences in the timing of payments from the payer, consisting of either (1) outright&#13;sale, in which payment is received from the payer based on standard terms, (2) capped installment sale, under which the system&#13;is sold for a series of payments that are capped not to exceed a prescribed or negotiated amount over a period of time or (3) installment&#13;sale under which Systems are paid for over a period of several months as long as the patient continues to use the System.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;Regardless of type of transaction, provided criteria&#13;for an enforceable contract are met, it is the Company&amp;#8217;s long-standing business practice to regard all home care agreements&#13;as transferring control to the patient upon shipment or delivery, in spite of possible payment cancelation under government or&#13;commercial programs where the payer is controlling the payment over specified time periods. For home care sales that feature installment&#13;payments, the ultimate amount of consideration received from Medicare, Medicaid or commercial payers can be significantly less&#13;than expected if the contract is terminated due to changes in the patient&amp;#8217;s status, including insurance coverage, hospitalization,&#13;death, or otherwise becoming unable to use the system. However, once delivered to a patient who needs the System, the patient is&#13;under no obligation to return the system should payments be terminated as a result of the described contingencies. As a result,&#13;the Company&amp;#8217;s product sales qualify for point in time revenue recognition. Control transfers to the patient, and revenue&#13;is recognized upon shipment of the system. At this point, physical possession and the significant risks and rewards of ownership&#13;are transferred to the patient and either a current or future right to payment is triggered (see additional discussion under &lt;i&gt;Accounts&#13;receivable&lt;/i&gt; and &lt;i&gt;Contract assets &lt;/i&gt;below).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;The Company&amp;#8217;s contractually stated transaction&#13;prices in the home care market are generally set by the terms of the contracts negotiated with insurance companies or by government&#13;programs. The transaction price for the Company&amp;#8217;s products may be further impacted by variable consideration. ASC 606 requires&#13;the Company to adjust the transaction price at contract inception and throughout the contract duration for the estimated value&#13;of payments to be received from insurance payers based on historical experience and other available information, subject to the&#13;constraint on estimates of variable consideration. Transactions requiring estimates of variable consideration primarily include&#13;(i) capped installment payments which are subject to the third-party payer&amp;#8217;s termination due to changes in insurance coverage,&#13;death or the patient&amp;#8217;s discontinued use of the system, (ii) contracts under appeal and (iii) patient responsibility amounts&#13;for deductibles, coinsurance, copays and other similar payments.&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;Although estimates may be made on a contract-by-contract&#13;basis, whenever possible, the Company uses all available information including historical collection patterns to estimate variable&#13;consideration for portfolios of contracts. The Company&amp;#8217;s estimates of variable consideration consist of amounts it may receive&#13;from insurance providers in excess of its initial revenue estimate due to patients meeting deductibles or coinsurance during the&#13;payment duration, changes to a patient&amp;#8217;s insurance status, changes in an insurance allowable, claims in appeals with Medicare&#13;and amounts received directly from patients for their allowable or coinsurance. The Company believes it has representative historical&#13;information to estimate the amount of variable consideration in relevant portfolios considering the significant experience it has&#13;with each portfolio and the similarity of patient accounts within a portfolio. The analysis includes steps to ensure that revenue&#13;recognized on a portfolio basis does not result in a material difference when compared with an individual contract approach. The&#13;Company also leverages its historical experience and all available relevant information for each portfolio of contracts to minimize&#13;the risk its estimates used to arrive at the transaction price will result in a significant reversal in the amount of cumulative&#13;revenue recognized when the uncertainty associated with the variable consideration is subsequently resolved. Variable consideration&#13;is included in the transaction price if, in the Company&amp;#8217;s judgment, it is probable that a significant future reversal of&#13;cumulative revenue under the contract will not occur.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;For example, for contracts in which the Company believes&#13;the criteria for reimbursement under government or commercial payer contracts have been met but for which coverage is unconfirmed&#13;or payments are under appeal, the Company has significant observable evidence of relatively consistent claims recovery experience&#13;over the prior three to five years. The Company believes the low volatility in historical claims approval rates for populations&#13;of patients whose demographics are similar to those of current patients provides reliable predictive value in arriving at estimates&#13;of variable consideration in such contracts. Similarly, historical payment trends for recovery of claims subject to payer installments&#13;and payments from patients have remained relatively consistent over the past five years. No significant changes in patient demographics&#13;or other relevant factors have occurred that would limit the predictive value of such payment trends in estimating variable consideration&#13;for current contracts. As a result, the Company believes its estimates of variable consideration are generally not subject to the&#13;risk of significant revenue reversal.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;For each type of variable consideration discussed&#13;above, there are a large number of contracts with similar characteristics with a wide range of possible transaction prices. For&#13;that reason, the Company uses the probability-weighted expected value method provided under ASC 606 to estimate variable consideration.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;The Company often receives payment from third-party&#13;payers for the SmartVest System sales over a period of time that may exceed one year. Despite these extended payment terms, no&#13;significant financing component is deemed to exist because the purpose of such terms is not to provide financing to the patient,&#13;the payer or the Company. Rather, the extended payment terms are mandated by the government or commercial insurance programs; the&#13;fundamental purpose of which is to avoid paying the full purchase price of equipment that may potentially be used by the patient&#13;for only a short period of time.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Institutional market. &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;The Company&amp;#8217;s&#13;institutional sales are made to adult pulmonology clinics, cystic fibrosis centers, neuromuscular clinics, pulmonary rehabilitation&#13;centers, hospitals and home health care centers. Sales to these institutions are negotiated with the individual institution or&#13;with group purchasing organizations, with payments received directly from the institution. No insurance reimbursement is involved.&#13;Generators are either sold or leased to the institutions and associated hoses and wraps (used in institutional settings rather&#13;than vests) are sold separately. Accordingly, each product is distinct and considered a separate performance obligation in sales&#13;to institutional customers. The agreements with institutions fall into two main types, distinguished by differences in the timing&#13;of transfer of control and timing of payments:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#9679;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;Outright sale &amp;#8211; Under these transactions, the Company sells its products for a prescribed or negotiated price. Transfer&#13;of control of the product, and associated revenue recognition, occurs at the time of shipment and payment is made within normal&#13;credit terms, usually within 30 days.&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#9679;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;Rentals - Under these transactions, the customer obtains a right to use the product for a period of time in exchange for consideration&#13;as usage occurs. These transactions are treated as operating leases and revenue is recognized ratably over the applicable rental&#13;period. Lease revenue recognized during the six months ended December 31, 2018 and 2017 were approximately $25,000 and $34,000,&#13;respectively.&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;International market. &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt; Sales to international&#13;markets are made directly to a number of independent distributors at fixed contract prices that are not subject to further adjustments&#13;for variable consideration. Transfer of control of the products occurs upon shipment or delivery to the distributor as applicable.&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Product Warranty. &lt;/b&gt;The Company offers warranties on its&#13;products. These warranties are assurance type warranties not sold on a standalone basis or are otherwise considered immaterial&#13;in the context of the contract, and therefore are not considered distinct performance obligations under ASC 606. The Company estimates&#13;the costs that may be incurred under its warranties and records a liability in the amount of such costs at the time the product&#13;is sold.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Accounts receivable. &lt;/b&gt;Accounts receivable include amounts&#13;billed to customers and third-party payers, for which only the passage of time is required before payment of consideration is due.&#13;Amounts due are stated at their net estimated realizable value.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Contract assets. &lt;/b&gt;Contract assets include amounts recognized&#13;as revenue that are estimates of variable consideration for Medicare appeals where the final determination of the insurance coverage&#13;amount is dependent on future approval of an appeal, or when the consideration due to the Company is dependent on a future event&#13;such as the patient meeting a deductible prior to the Company&amp;#8217;s claim being processed by the payer. Contract assets are classified&#13;as current as amounts will turn into accounts receivable and be collected during the Company&amp;#8217;s normal business operating&#13;cycle. Contract assets are reclassified to accounts receivable when the right to receive payment is unconditional.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Incremental costs to obtain a contract. &lt;/b&gt;Sales incentives&#13;paid to sales representatives are eligible for capitalization as they are incremental costs that would not have been incurred without&#13;entering into a specific sales arrangement and are recoverable through the expected margin on the transaction&lt;b&gt;. &lt;/b&gt;However,&#13;the recovery period is less than one year as the performance obligation is satisfied upon shipment or delivery. Consequently, the&#13;Company will apply the practical expedient provided by ASC 340-40-25-4 and expense sales incentives as incurred. These costs are&#13;included in selling, general and administrative expenses in the Company&amp;#8217;s condensed statements of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Other practical expedients&lt;/b&gt;. The Company did not elect&#13;to apply any of the four optional practical expedients that provide relief from applying the requirements of ASC 606 to certain&#13;types of contracts in the comparative periods presented when the full retrospective method of adoption is applied.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Contract balances. &lt;/b&gt;The following table provides information&#13;about accounts receivable and contracts assets from contracts with customers:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 95%; margin-left: 0.5in; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="text-align: center; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" align="center" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 95%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="text-align: center;    &lt;td colspan="6" style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; border-bottom: Black 1px solid"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;For the six months ended December 31,&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;     <us-gaap:InventoryDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Note&amp;#160;3.     <us-gaap:IntangibleAssetsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 4.  Finite-life Intangible Assets &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The carrying value of patents and trademarks includes the original&#13;cost of obtaining the patents, periodic renewal fees, and other costs associated with maintaining and defending patent and trademark&#13;rights. Patents and trademarks are amortized over their estimated useful lives, generally 15 and 12 years, respectively. Accumulated&#13;amortization was $956,000 and $902,000 at December 31, 2018 and June 30, 2018, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The activity and balances of finite-life intangible assets were&#13;approximately as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;     <us-gaap:ProductWarrantyDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Note 5. Warranty Liability&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The Company provides a lifetime warranty on its products to&#13;the prescribed patient for sales within the U.S. and a three-year warranty for all institutional sales and sales to individuals&#13;outside the U.S. The Company estimates the costs that may be incurred under its warranty and records a liability in the amount&#13;of such costs at the time the product is shipped. Factors that affect the Company&amp;#8217;s warranty liability include the number&#13;of units shipped, historical and anticipated rates of warranty claims, the product&amp;#8217;s useful life and cost per claim. The&#13;Company periodically assesses the adequacy of its recorded warranty liability and adjusts the amounts as necessary.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Changes in the Company&amp;#8217;s warranty liability were approximately&#13;as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;     <us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Note 6. Income Taxes&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the &amp;#8220;Tax Act&amp;#8221;) significantly&#13;revised future and ongoing U.S. corporate tax obligations by, among other things, lowering U.S. corporate income tax rates. Since&#13;the Company has a June 30 fiscal year-end, the lower corporate income tax rate was phased in, resulting in a blended U.S. statutory&#13;federal rate of approximately 28% for fiscal 2018, and 21% for subsequent fiscal years. The Tax Act also eliminates the domestic&#13;production manufacturing deduction effective for the Company&amp;#8217;s tax year beginning July 1, 2018.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;In connection with the adoption of ASC 606, the Company intends&#13;to file Form 3115 (Change in Accounting Method) with its federal tax return for the period ending June 30, 2019. Under Rev. Proc.&#13;2018-29, certain accounting method changes related to a taxpayers&amp;#8217; adoption of the new revenue recognition standards under&#13;ASC 606 will qualify for automatic approval by the Internal Revenue Service. As a result of the accounting method change, the Company&#13;estimates an increase in taxable income of approximately $2.2 million, which is to be recognized over four consecutive years. Therefore,&#13;the estimated tax liability resulting from taxable income recognition in year one of approximately $140,000 has been reclassified&#13;from deferred taxes to current income tax payable.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-indent: 0in"&gt;On a quarterly basis, the Company estimates&#13;its effective tax rate for the full fiscal year and records a quarterly income tax provision based on the anticipated rate. As&#13;the year progresses, the Company refines its estimate based on the facts and circumstances by each tax jurisdiction. Income tax&#13;expense was estimated at approximately $311,000 and $369,000 and the effective tax rates were 45.2% and 40.9%, respectively, for&#13;the three and six months ended December 31, 2018. Estimated income tax expense for the three and six months ended December 31,&#13;2018 includes a discrete deferred tax expense of approximately $126,000 related to unexercised fully-vested stock options that&#13;expired on November 24, 2018 and a discrete current tax benefit of approximately $9,000 related to the excess tax benefit of non-qualified&#13;stock options exercised during the period. The net impact of these discrete events increased the estimated effective tax rates&#13;by 17.0% and 13.0% during the three and six months ended December 31, 2018, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-indent: 0in"&gt;Income tax expense was estimated at approximately&#13;$346,000 and $360,000 and the effective tax rates were 45.2% and 41.8%, respectively, for the three and six months ended December&#13;31, 2017. Estimated income tax expense for the three and six months ended December 31, 2017 includes a discrete deferred tax expense&#13;of approximately $160,000 as a result of re-measuring certain deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the rates at which they&#13;are expected to reverse in future periods under the Tax Act. Additionally, a discrete tax benefit of approximately $2,000 and $27,000&#13;was recognized during the three and six months ended December 31, 2017, respectively, as a result of greater federal and state&#13;research and development tax credits than what was originally estimated in our tax provision for our fiscal year ended June 30,&#13;2017. The net impact of these discrete events increased the estimated effective tax rates by 20.6% and 15.5% during the three and&#13;six months ended December 31, 2017, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;Note 7. Financing Arrangements&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The Company has a credit facility that provides for a revolving&#13;line of credit and a term loan.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Effective December 18, 2018, the Company renewed its $2,500,000 revolving line of credit.&#13;There was no outstanding principal balance on the line of credit as of December 31, 2018 or June 30, 2018. Interest on borrowings&#13;under the line of credit, if any, accrues at the prime rate (5.50% at December 31, 2018) less 1.00% and is payable monthly. The&#13;amount eligible for borrowing on the line of credit is limited to the lesser of $2,500,000 or 57.00% of eligible accounts receivable&#13;and the line of credit expires on December 18, 2019, if not renewed. At December 31, 2018, the maximum $2,500,000 was eligible&#13;for borrowing. The line of credit is secured by a security interest in substantially all of the tangible and intangible assets&#13;of the Company.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;In connection with the credit facility, the Company also had&#13;a term loan, which had an outstanding principal balance of approximately $1,103,000 as of June 30, 2018 and an interest rate of&#13;3.88%. The unamortized debt issuance cost associated with this debt was approximately $2,000 as of June 30, 2018. The term loan&#13;matured on December 18, 2018, and the Company utilized cash to repay the required balloon payment of approximately $1,085,000.&#13;Payment obligations under the term loan were secured by a mortgage on the Company&amp;#8217;s real property, which security interest&#13;was released upon payoff. The Company no longer has any obligations under the term loan.&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The documents governing the line of credit contain certain financial&#13;and nonfinancial covenants that include a minimum tangible net worth covenant of not less than $10,125,000 and restrictions on&#13;the Company&amp;#8217;s ability to incur certain additional indebtedness or pay dividends.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:DisclosureOfCompensationRelatedCostsShareBasedPaymentsTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.75in; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 8. Stock-Based Compensation&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.75in; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;In November 2017, the Company&amp;#8217;s shareholders approved&#13;the 2017 Omnibus Incentive Plan (the &amp;#8220;2017 Plan&amp;#8221;) which supersedes the 2014 Equity Incentive Plan (the &amp;#8220;2014&#13;Plan&amp;#8221;). The 2017 Plan allows the Company&amp;#8217;s Board of Directors to grant stock options, stock appreciation rights, restricted&#13;stock, restricted stock units and other stock-based awards, as well as cash incentive awards to all employees, non-employee directors,&#13;and advisors or consultants of the Company. The vesting schedule and term for each award are determined by the Board upon each&#13;grant. The maximum number of shares of common stock available for issuance under the 2017 Plan is 900,000. There were 581,751 stock&#13;options granted under the 2014 Plan and prior plans outstanding as of December 31, 2018. There were 200,250 stock options and 50,000&#13;restricted shares issued under the 2017 Plan outstanding and 649,750 shares available for grant under the 2017 Plan as of December&#13;31, 2018.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The Company recorded approximately $501,000 and $386,000 of&#13;compensation expense related to current and past grants of stock options and restricted stock for the six months ended December&#13;31, 2018 and 2017, respectively. This expense is included in selling, general and administrative expense. As of December 31, 2018,&#13;approximately $1,164,000 of total unrecognized compensation expense related to non-vested equity awards was expected to be recognized&#13;over a weighted average period of approximately 0.9 years.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The Company recognizes compensation expense related to share-based&#13;payment transactions in the financial statements based on the estimated fair value of the award issued. The fair value of each&#13;option is estimated using the Black-Scholes pricing model at the time of award grant. The Company estimates the expected life&#13;of options based on the expected holding period by the option holder. The risk-free interest rate is based upon observed U.S.&#13;Treasury interest rates for the expected term of the options. The Company makes assumptions with respect to expected stock price&#13;volatility based upon the historical volatility of its stock price. Forfeitures are estimated at the time of grant and revised&#13;in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from initial estimates. Forfeitures are estimated based on the percentage of&#13;awards expected to vest, taking into consideration the seniority level of the award recipient.&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The following assumptions were used to&#13;estimate the fair value of stock options granted:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; Stock option transactions during the six months ended December 31, 2018 are&#13;summarized as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; background-color: rgb(214,243,232); font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 70%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;Outstanding at June 30, 2018 &lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 1%;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;(55,525&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: left;    &lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;Outstanding at December 31, 2018 &lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 2pt; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 3px double; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-align: right"&gt;782,001&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 2pt; text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 2pt; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: right; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;3.88&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 2pt; text-align: left; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The intrinsic value of an option is the amount by which the&#13;fair value of the underlying stock exceeds its exercise price. At December 31, 2018, the weighted average remaining contractual&#13;term for all outstanding stock options was 7.49 years and their aggregate intrinsic value was approximately $1,104,000. Outstanding&#13;at December 31, 2018 were 782,001 stock options issued to employees, of which 432,340 were exercisable and had an aggregate intrinsic&#13;value of approximately $1,047,000.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Restricted Stock&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;The Company&amp;#8217;s 2017 Plan permits the grant of other stock-based&#13;awards. Historically, the Company makes restricted stock grants to key employees and non-employee directors that vest over six&#13;months to three years.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;During the six months ended December 31, 2018, the Company issued&#13;restricted stock awards to employees totaling 30,000 shares of common stock, with a vesting term of one to three years and a fair&#13;value of $5.42 per share, and to directors totaling 10,000 shares of common stock, with a vesting term of six months and a fair&#13;value of $5.70 per share. The restricted stock&amp;#8217;s fair value per share represents the closing price of its common stock on&#13;the date of the grant. Restricted stock transactions during the six months ended December 31, 2018 are summarized as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;     <us-gaap:ScheduleOfShareBasedCompensationStockOptionsActivityTableTextBlock contextRef="From2018-07-01to2018-12-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"&gt; Stock option transactions during the six months ended December 31, 2018 are&#13;summarized as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_dei_EntityEmergingGrowthCompany">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">

<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Indicate whether the registrant is one of the following: (1) Large Accelerated Filer, (2) Accelerated Filer, (3) Non-accelerated Filer, (4) Smaller Reporting Company (Non-accelerated), (5) Smaller Reporting Accelerated Filer or (6) Smaller Reporting Company and Large Accelerated Filer. Definitions of these categories are stated in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange Act. This information should be based on the registrant's current or most recent filing containing the related disclosure.</p></div>

<div style="display: none;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AccountsPayableCurrent">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Carrying value as of the balance sheet date of liabilities incurred (and for which invoices have typically been received) and payable to vendors for goods and services received that are used in an entity's business. Used to reflect the current portion of the liabilities (due within one year or within the normal operating cycle if longer).</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.19(a))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-122682<br></p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ Details</a><div style="display: none;"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AccountsReceivableNetCurrent">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Amount due from customers or clients, within one year of the balance sheet date (or the normal operating cycle, whichever is longer), for goods or services (including trade receivables) that have been delivered or sold in the normal course of business, reduced to the estimated net realizable fair value by an allowance established by the entity of the amount it deems uncertain of collection.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/disclosureRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 606<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 50<br> -Paragraph 8<br> -Subparagraph (a)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=109196051&amp;loc=SL49130549-203045<br><br>Reference 2: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02(3))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-122682<br></p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ Details</a><div style="display: none;"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<td><strong> Name:</strong></td>
<td style="white-space:nowrap;">us-gaap_AccountsReceivableNetCurrent</td>

<tr>
<td style="padding-right: 4px;white-space:nowrap;"><strong> Namespace Prefix:</strong></td>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AdditionalPaidInCapital">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Excess of issue price over par or stated value of the entity's capital stock and amounts received from other transactions involving the entity's stock or stockholders. Includes adjustments to additional paid in capital. Some examples of such adjustments include recording the issuance of debt with a beneficial conversion feature and certain tax consequences of equity instruments awarded to employees. Use this element for the aggregate amount of additional paid-in capital associated with common and preferred stock. For additional paid-in capital associated with only common stock, use the element additional paid in capital, common stock. For additional paid-in capital associated with only preferred stock, use the element additional paid in capital, preferred stock.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02(30)(a)(1))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-122682<br></p></div>

Used to reflect the current portion of the liabilities (due within one year or within the normal operating cycle if longer).</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_StockholdersEquity">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Total of all stockholders' equity (deficit) items, net of receivables from officers, directors, owners, and affiliates of the entity which are attributable to the parent. The amount of the economic entity's stockholders' equity attributable to the parent excludes the amount of stockholders' equity which is allocable to that ownership interest in subsidiary equity which is not attributable to the parent (noncontrolling interest, minority interest). This excludes temporary equity and is sometimes called permanent equity.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 310<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 2<br> -Subparagraph (SAB Topic 4.E)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=27010918&amp;loc=d3e74512-122707<br><br>Reference 2: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02(31))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-122682<br><br>Reference 3: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02(29))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-122682<br><br>Reference 4: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02(30))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-122682<br></p></div>

<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Total number of common shares of an entity that have been sold or granted to shareholders (includes common shares that were issued, repurchased and remain in the treasury). These shares represent capital invested by the firm's shareholders and owners, and may be all or only a portion of the number of shares authorized. Shares issued include shares outstanding and shares held in the treasury.</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_CommonStockSharesOutstanding">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Number of shares of common stock outstanding. Common stock represent the ownership interest in a corporation.</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_EarningsPerShareDiluted">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>The amount of net income (loss) for the period available to each share of common stock or common unit outstanding during the reporting period and to each share or unit that would have been outstanding assuming the issuance of common shares or units for all dilutive potential common shares or units outstanding during the reporting period.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/exampleRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_ResearchAndDevelopmentExpense">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>The aggregate costs incurred (1) in a planned search or critical investigation aimed at discovery of new knowledge with the hope that such knowledge will be useful in developing a new product or service, a new process or technique, or in bringing about a significant improvement to an existing product or process; or (2) to translate research findings or other knowledge into a plan or design for a new product or process or for a significant improvement to an existing product or process whether intended for sale or the entity's use, during the reporting period charged to research and development projects, including the costs of developing computer software up to the point in time of achieving technological feasibility, and costs allocated in accounting for a business combination to in-process projects deemed to have no alternative future use.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 985<br> -SubTopic 20<br> -Section 50<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6501960&amp;loc=d3e128462-111756<br><br>Reference 2: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 730<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 50<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6420194&amp;loc=d3e21568-108373<br></p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ Details</a><div style="display: none;"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_Revenues">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>Amount of revenue recognized from goods sold, services rendered, insurance premiums, or other activities that constitute an earning process. Includes, but is not limited to, investment and interest income before deduction of interest expense when recognized as a component of revenue, and sales and trading gain (loss).</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/disclosureRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 280<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 50<br> -Paragraph 22<br> -Subparagraph (a)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=115929826&amp;loc=d3e8736-108599<br><br>Reference 2: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 220<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 2<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-03.1)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=115205541&amp;loc=SL114868664-224227<br><br>Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/disclosureRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 280<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 50<br> -Paragraph 32<br> -Subparagraph (a)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=115929826&amp;loc=d3e8933-108599<br><br>Reference 4: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/disclosureRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 280<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 50<br> -Paragraph 22<br> -Subparagraph (b)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=115929826&amp;loc=d3e8736-108599<br></p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_SellingGeneralAndAdministrativeExpense">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>The aggregate total costs related to selling a firm's product and services, as well as all other general and administrative expenses. Direct selling expenses (for example, credit, warranty, and advertising) are expenses that can be directly linked to the sale of specific products. Indirect selling expenses are expenses that cannot be directly linked to the sale of specific products, for example telephone expenses, Internet, and postal charges. General and administrative expenses include salaries of non-sales personnel, rent, utilities, communication, etc.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 330<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 30<br> -Paragraph 8<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=68048583&amp;loc=d3e3636-108311<br><br>Reference 2: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 220<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 2<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-03.4)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=115205541&amp;loc=SL114868664-224227<br></p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AmortizationOfIntangibleAssets">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- Definition</a><div><p>The aggregate expense charged against earnings to allocate the cost of intangible assets (nonphysical assets not used in production) in a systematic and rational manner to the periods expected to benefit from such assets. As a noncash expense, this element is added back to net income when calculating cash provided by or used in operations using the indirect method.</p></div>

http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=115205541&amp;loc=SL114868664-224227<br><br>Reference 6: http://fasb.org/us-gaap/role/ref/legacyRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards <head>
<title></title>
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="report.css">
<script type="text/javascript" src="Show.js">/* Do Not Remove This Comment */</script><script type="text/javascript">
							function toggleNextSibling (e) {
							if (e.nextSibling.style.display=='none') {
							e.nextSibling.style.display='block';
